nl.strohalm.cyclos.services.stats
Class StatisticalResultDTO

java.lang.Object
  nl.strohalm.cyclos.utils.DataObject
      nl.strohalm.cyclos.services.stats.StatisticalResultDTO
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
public class StatisticalResultDTO
extends DataObject

this class is the base value object containing the statistical data to be shown in the jsp. It is used for rendering the data tables. For each statistic table, the following must be done:

  • Assign the data array via the constructor. This is a two dimensional array of Numbers
  • set the baseKey. This is the basekey for looking up strings in the language resource bundles
    The baseKey is used for the following items, so these keys must be provided in the language resource bundle:
    • plain basekey is used for the graph title
    • basekey.title is used as the title of the surrounding window
    • basekey.yAxis is used as the title along the y-axis of the graph
    • basekey.xAxis is used as the title along the x-axis of the graph
    • basekey.rowN is used as the name of the Nth data row in the table
    • basekey.rowN.short is used as a shorter version of this name, to appear at the x-Axis below the Nth category in the graph. Note that this string must be as short as possible to fit in the graph.
    • Helpfile: all the dots (.) are deleted from the basekey, the elements between the dots are capitalized for their first letter, and a .jsp is appended. This needs to be provided as a help file.
  • set the row keys, or the row Headers. See setRowKeys method for details.
  • set the column keys or the column headers.
  • If any filters were used, you must pass the used filters via the setFilter methods. Best use the corresponding methods of StatisticalService: passPaymentFilter and passGroupFilter.
Optionally, the following may be set:
  • set graphType
  • in addition to row keys, set one or more row headers for specific strings which need not to be taken from the language resource bundle. You can set one at a time, or an array with all of the headers.
  • same for column headers, you can also set one or more.
  • you can set column subheaders; usually this is used to indicate the units in the column. This will only show up in the table, not in the graph
  • set a subtitle for the graph and table
  • set the multiGraph field in case you want to display a separate graph for each table row or column
  • set showTable to false - this makes that the table is not shown. The default is showTable = true. Don't forget to set a graphtype if showTable is false, otherwise nothing is shown.
  • set a scale Factor for the x-axis. (like "x 1000")
  • set the graph dimensions. See setGraphDimensions(TableToGraph, Integer, Integer)
  • if any unit along the x or y-axis is to be displayed, you can pass this via the setXAxisUnits method or setYAxisUnits method.
  • You can set markers for the graph. A marker is a horizontal or vertical line which is drawn through the whole graph in order to indicate a special result value or domain value. For example, a vertical line to indicate "today" in a graph with dates along the x-axis.

Author:
rinke
See Also:

orderSeries

public void orderSeries(byte[] seriesOrder)
Allows you to order the series according to an array of bytes with order numbers. Of course, this can only be done after the tableCells and seriesNames have been set to the graph/table. All corresponding headers and keys, as well as the data is reordered.
Example:
Suppose the tableCells contain the following points: 
 { { 5, 7, 2 }, { 5, 7, 2 }, { 5, 7, 2 }, { 5, 7, 2 }, { 5, 7, 2 } }
Suppose the seriesOrder param is {2, 1, 3};
After running this method, the tableCells will look like this: 
 { { 7, 5, 2 }, { 7, 5, 2 }, { 7, 5, 2 }, { 7, 5, 2 }, { 7, 5, 2 } }

Parameters:
seriesOrder - an array of bytes containing the index numbers of the series. The values do not need to be subsequent numbers; also {16, 8, 10} would be possible. If a value is encountered more than once, corresponding elements are considered equal at ordering.

setGraphDimensions

public void setGraphDimensions(StatisticalResultDTO.TableToGraph tableToGraph,
                               java.lang.Integer seriesCount,
                               java.lang.Integer categoriesCount)
This setter sets three properties which can only be set at once (because the second and third may only be set AFTER the first is set, I created a 3-in-1-setter).
It takes care for the number of categories and series in the graph. There is no obligation to set this; if you do not set it, it follows the default behaviour. All params accept null values, which also corresponds to the default behaviour.
The default behaviour is:
  • a table column in the graph will be shown as a serie in the graph, meaning that it shows up in the legend of the graph.
  • the number of table columns equals the number of series in the graph.
  • the number of table rows equals the number of categories along the x-axis of the graph.

Parameters:
tableToGraph - a TableToGraph enum which determines how the orientation of the graph is. If this is set to null the default behaviour will be kept, meaning that table columns are converted to graph series.
Note that this param only needs to be set in exceptional cases. Normally you can just pass null.
seriesCount - an Integer which indicates the number of series in the graph. If (and only if) this is smaller than the number of columns in the table (or the number of rows, depending on the columnIsCategory param), then only part of the available series is shown in the graph, starting the count at the first series.
A null parameter enforces the default behaviour.
Example: if columnIsCategory is false, the table has 5 columns, and seriesCount = 4, then only the first 4 columns of the table are shown in the graph; the last column of the table is not shown.
categoriesCount - as with seriesCount, only now for categories along the x-axis of the graph.

setRowKeys

public void setRowKeys(StatisticalResultDTO.ResourceKey[] rowKeys)
                throws InconsistentDataDimensionsException
A setter for the categories or table row headers. Use this version if you need a param inside one or more of the keys. Usage: final StatisticalResultDTO.ResourceKey[] rowKeys = new StatisticalResultDTO.ResourceKey[n]; rowKeys[k] = new StatisticalResultDTO.ResourceKey(keyStringForKeyWithoutArgument); rowKeys[m] = new StatisticalResultDTO.ResourceKey(keyStringForKeyWithArgument, new Object[] { arg0, arg1 }); statisticalResultDTO.setRowKeys(rowKeys);

Parameters:
rowKeys - = categories. An Array containing ResourceKey Objects. The headers for each row, and the categories along the x-axis of the graph. Note that these are the KEYS for the row header strings; these corresponding strings are found in the language resource bundle.
Throws:
InconsistentDataDimensionsException. - Raised if the length of the String array parameter does not match the length of the already set 2 dimensional array with the data (and if the number of rows > 0).
InconsistentDataDimensionsException

setRowKeys

public void setRowKeys(java.lang.String[] rowKeys)
                throws InconsistentDataDimensionsException
a Simple setter for the categories or table row headers. Use this version simply when only needing Strings for keys, without any parameters.

Parameters:
rowKeys - = categories. The headers for each row, and the categories along the x-axis of the graph. Note that these are the KEYS for the row header strings; these corresponding strings are found in the language resource bundle.
Throws:
InconsistentDataDimensionsException. - Raised if the length of the String array parameter does not match the length of the already set 2 dimensional array with the data (and if the number of rows > 0).
InconsistentDataDimensionsException

setXAxisUnits

public void setXAxisUnits(java.lang.String axisUnits)
if any x-axis unit is to be displayed with the x-axis label, you can pass it via this method. If you need a key in stead of a string, we suggest you don't use this method, but just place the unit between parenthesis behind the .xAxis string in the resouce bundle.

Parameters:
axisUnits - the String to be displayed along the x-axis. It will be placed between () after the normal x-axis label.

setYAxisUnits

public void setYAxisUnits(java.lang.String axisUnits)
if any y-axis unit is to be displayed with the y-axis label, you can pass it via this method.

Parameters:
axisUnits - the String to be displayed along the y-axis. It will be placed between () after the normal y-axis label.
